How to Coordinate Edge Devices for Over-the-Air Federated Learning?

Mohammad Ali Sedaghat1, Ali Bereyhi2, Saba Asaad2, and Ralf R. MÃ¼ller2, 1Qualcomm CDMA Technologies GmbH Nuremberg
2Friedrich-Alexander UniversitÃ¤t Erlangen-NÃ¼rnberg (FAU)
msedagha@qti.qualcomm.com, {ali.bereyhi, saba.asaad, ralf.r.mueller}@fau.de
Abstract

This work studies the task of device coordination in wireless networks for over-the-air federated learning (OTA-FL). For conventional metrics of aggregation error, the task is shown to describe the zero-forcing (ZF) and minimum mean squared error (MMSE) schemes and reduces to the NP-hard problem of subset selection. We tackle this problem by studying properties of the optimal scheme. Our analytical results reveal that this scheme is found by searching among the leaves of a tree with favorable monotonic features. Invoking these features, we develop a low-complexity algorithm that approximates the optimal scheme by tracking a dominant path of the tree sequentially. Our numerical investigations show that the proposed algorithm closely tracks the optimal scheme.

Index Terms:
Over-the-air communication, federated Learning, multi-antenna, mean squared error.

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is a privacy-preserving framework for distributed learning that enables edge devices to address a learning task, e.g., training a global model, jointly without need for sharing their local data [1, 2, 3]. This ensures device privacy and provides a joint scheme for learning that performs considerably better than individual distributed learning while keeping the communication load of the system tractable [4, 5, 6].

The promising learning performance in FL comes along with several challenges which are roughly divided into the three categories of privacy, statistical properties of local datasets and communication-efficiency. With respect to privacy, FL has been shown to be vulnerable against model inversion attack [7, 8]. This follows from the fact that edge devices in FL share their local models that are often strongly correlated with their local data [9, 10]. Statistical properties of local datasets further refers to the sensitivity of FL against data distribution. Initial studies on FL have shown promising performance and fast convergence of this framework for homogeneous local datasets. Nevertheless, obtaining these favorable behaviors have been shown to face some analytical challenges when we deviate from simple statistical models for local datasets [11]. This is in particular crucial, as the exact statistical model of data is rather unknown in practice.

This study focuses on the latter class of challenges in FL, i.e., communication-efficiency, that refers to communication-related challenges, when the FL framework is to be implemented in a wireless network. In fact, FL schemes require several rounds of communication between a central node, often called the parameter server (PS), and the edge devices. This is in particular challenging when the scheme runs over remote wireless devices introducing various sources of imperfection to the setting, e.g., rate-limited communication links and noisy assessment of local model parameters [12, 13, 14].

I-A Over-the-Air Federated Learning

FL performs distributed learning in three main phases:

  1. 1.

    Starting with an initial global model, edge devices learn a model locally from their datasets. They then share the local models with the PS.

  2. 2.

    The PS collects the local models and aggregates them into a global model.

  3. 3.

    The global model is sent back to the devices, and the devices repeat local learning via the new global model.

The PS and edge devices keep iterating these three phases for several communication rounds until they converge.

Classical approaches for implementation of FL in a wireless network suggest a separate decoding and aggregation at the PS[15, 16]. This means that the PS decodes first the received local models and then combines the decoded models into a global model via a predefined aggregation policy. An alternative approach is proposed in [17] which invokes the idea of analog function computation [18] to perform model aggregation directly over the air. We refer to this latter approach as over-the-air FL (OTA-FL) in this paper. OTA-FL invokes the signal combination in the multiple access channel to realize the predefined aggregation policy directly over-the-air. In other words, the edge devices in OTA-FL transmit their local models with proper scaling, such the desired model aggregation is calculated from the a linearly-transformed version of the received signal at the PS. In various use-cases, OTA-FL is more efficient than separate decoding and aggregation [19]. In fact, OTA-FL does not need to orthogonalize communication resources, i.e., allocate individual bandwidth and time slot to every device, and hence it enjoys both advantages of lower computation and resource efficiency [20, 21, 22].

I-B Contributions and Organization

As OTA-FL relies on the uplink channel for model aggregation, coordination plays a key role in its performance. In fact, the PS and devices need to agree on a communication protocol, such that the over-the-air aggregated model is as close as possible to the desired form. Prior studies often consider a basic approach for coordination that is known to be sub-optimal from the information theoretic point of view. In this work, we study the concept of coordination in OTA-FL in great details. In this respect, we first formulate an optimal coordination scheme for a given metric of aggregation error mathematically. We then show that using the conventional metric of mean squared error (MSE) for aggregation error, the optimal coordination scheme reduces to an MSE minimization problem, while the commonly-used strategy for coordination is simply zero-forcing. Our analyses show that both strategies reduce to the NP-hard problem of subset selection and hence deal with the same level of hardness. We tackle the problem of subset selection in both minimum MSE and zero-forcing schemes by studying the properties of the solution. Our investigations reveal that the solution in both cases can be found by searching over the leaves of a tree with some monotonic properties. In the light of these properties, we propose low-complexity algorithms which sequentially approximate the solution by tracking a dominant path towards leaves. Our simulation results show that the proposed tree-based algorithm can track the optimal performance very closely while enjoying a drastically lower computational complexity.

The remaining of this manuscript is organized as follows: We first formulate the problem concretely in Section II. Minimum MSE and zero-forcing coordination schemes are then illustrated in Sections III and IV , respectively. Sections V and VI investigates the analytical properties of the zero-forcing and minimum MSE schemes, respectively, and propose a tree-based algorithm for their approximation with low complexity. The validity of the derivations are confirmed through numerical investigation in Section VII. Finally, Section VIII concludes the paper.

II Problem Formulation

A wireless network with Lğ¿L single-antenna edge devices and a PS is considered. The devices employ an FL scheme, e.g., federated averaging, to address a common learning task, e.g., training a given model, jointly over their distributed local datasets. The PS is equipped with an Nğ‘N-element array-antenna. Throughout the analyses, we assume that Nâ‰¥Lğ‘ğ¿N\geq L. This assumption is however taken for the sake of brevity. The case of N<Lğ‘ğ¿N<L is then discussed separately as a remark; see Remark 1.

At the beginning of each coherence interval, the devices send predefined pilots in their uplink channels. The PS then estimates the channel state information (CSI) based on the received signals. For simplicity, we assume that the pilots are mutually orthogonal and that the estimation error is negligible. Hence, the PS knows the CSI perfectly. Throughout the analyses, we assume that the channels experience frequency-flat fading processes. This models transmission over a channel with a narrow frequency band. The derivations are in principle extendable to wide-band transmission in multi-carrier systems with frequency selective fading processes.

II-A OTA-FL Setting

II-C Coordination Schemes for the OTA-FL Setting

To establish FL in the network, the PS needs to coordinate the devices periodically: after the uplink training phase at the beginning of a coherence interval, the PS specifies the uplink scaling coefficients of the devices, i.e., {bâ„“}subscriptğ‘â„“\left\{b_{\ell}\right\}, and the linear receiver ğ¦ğ¦\mathbf{m}. The devices are then informed about their scaling coefficients by a downlink transmission. Afterwards, throughout the coherence interval, the PS and devices carry out their communication according to the OTA-FL scheme described in SectionÂ II-A using the coefficients and receiver specified in the training phase. It is worth mentioning that the PS only shares the scaling coefficients with the devices and not the complete CSI.

In general, the optimality of a coordination strategy depends on the choice of metric that determines the quality of the FL scheme. A good approach is to consider the aggregation error as the metric and design the coordination strategy, such that the error is minimized222This is in particular effective, since the MSE of estimated global model directly affects the learning quality of the FL scheme [17].. In this case, the optimal coordination strategy is formulated as

(ğ¦â‹†,ğâ‹†)=argminğ¦âˆˆâ„‚N,|bâ„“|2â‰¤PÏµâ€‹(ğ¦,ğ).superscriptğ¦â‹†superscriptğâ‹†subscriptargminformulae-sequenceğ¦superscriptâ„‚ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘â„“2ğ‘ƒitalic-Ïµğ¦ğ\displaystyle\left(\mathbf{m}^{\star},\mathbf{B}^{\star}\right)=\operatorname*{argmin}_{\mathbf{m}\in\mathbb{C}^{N},\left|b_{\ell}\right|^{2}\leq P}\epsilon\left(\mathbf{m},\mathbf{B}\right). (12)

This is in fact a minimum MSE (MMSE) problem. We hence refer to this strategy as MMSE coordination. Due to its non-convexity, MMSE coordination is computationally intractable in a generic network.

An alternative approach for coordination is to use the idea of zero-forcing (ZF) [17, 24]. In this approach, the PS ignores noise in the channel and coordinates the devices, such that the noise-free version of the estimated global model constructs the desired global model. From (6), this means that the PS finds ğ¦ğ¦\mathbf{m} and {bâ„“}subscriptğ‘â„“\left\{b_{\ell}\right\}, such that

ğ¦ğ–³â€‹ğ¡â„“â€‹bâ„“=Ï•â„“.superscriptğ¦ğ–³subscriptğ¡â„“subscriptğ‘â„“subscriptitalic-Ï•â„“\displaystyle\mathbf{m}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{h}_{\ell}b_{\ell}=\phi_{\ell}. (13)

In this case, the aggregation error reduces to

III MMSE Coordination for OTA-FL

The design problem for MMSE coordination is non-convex and generally challenging to solve. Nevertheless, forÂ someÂ particular cases, the solution can be derived tractably. An instance is given in [25], where the solution of a mathematically similar problem is derived for an uplink scenario with a single-antenna PS in closed form, despite its non-convexity. Motivated by this result, we present in the sequel some preliminary analyses. We show that the problem in the general case with a multi-antenna PS is more complicated and unlike the single-antenna case, the optimal MMSE scheme cannot be derived analytically. The analyses however give some important insights on MMSE coordination that pave the way for the proposed algorithms in next sections. We start the analyses by the following lemma:

Lemma 1.

With MMSE coordination in the network, there is at least one device that transmits with the maximum transmit power Pğ‘ƒP.

Proof.

The proof is given by contradiction: assume that all the devices transmit with power less than Pğ‘ƒP while coordinated via the MMSE scheme in (12). This means that |bâ„“â‹†|2<Psuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘â„“â‹†2ğ‘ƒ\left|b_{\ell}^{\star}\right|^{2}<P. We now construct new scaling coefficients as b^â„“=Îºâ€‹bâ„“â‹†subscript^ğ‘â„“ğœ…superscriptsubscriptğ‘â„“â‹†\hat{b}_{\ell}=\kappa b_{\ell}^{\star}, where Îº>1ğœ…1\kappa>1 is chosen such that

The results of LemmasÂ 1-3 imply that the main challenge in MMSE coordination is to find set ğ”»ğ”»\mathbb{D}, i.e., the devices that need to transmit with maximum power. This is in general an integer programming problem. In SectionÂ  VI, we propose a low-complexity algorithm to approximate this set. To state this algorithm, we need first to present some analytical results on ZF coordination. In the light of these results, we present our low-complexity algorithm for MMSE coordination.

IV ZF Coordination for OTA-FL

ZF coordination sets the first term of the aggregation error to zero while keeping the transmit powers below Pğ‘ƒP. This leads to a closed-form scaling coefficients, c.f. (16), and an expression for the receiver in terms of a quadratic programming problem, i.e., (15). The ZF scheme can be seen as a mismatched version of MMSE coordination in which the PS postulates noise to be zero-variance. In this section, we invoke this interpretation and extend the analytic results of SectionÂ III to ZF coordination.

We start the analysis by deriving a genie-aided form of ZF coordination. To this end, we partition the devices into subsets ğ”»zfsuperscriptğ”»zf\mathbb{D}^{\mathrm{zf}} and ğ”»Â¯zfsuperscriptÂ¯ğ”»zf\bar{\mathbb{D}}^{\mathrm{zf}} with the former denoting those that transmit with maximum power Pğ‘ƒP and the latter being itsÂ complement.Â Similar to ğ”»ğ”»\mathbb{D}, the set ğ”»zfsuperscriptğ”»zf{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}} cannot be empty.

Lemma 4.

With ZF coordination in the network, there is at least one device that transmits with the maximum power Pğ‘ƒP.

Proof.

The proof is given by contradiction following identical steps as in the proof of LemmaÂ 1. âˆ

We can further develop a similar result as in LemmaÂ 3 for ZF coordination: if one knows ğ”»zfsuperscriptğ”»zf\mathbb{D}^{\mathrm{zf}}; then, the receiver ğ¦zfsuperscriptğ¦zf\mathbf{m}^{\rm zf} is given by the following lemma.

Lemma 5.

Given ğ”»zfsuperscriptğ”»zf{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}}, the receiver ğ¦zfsuperscriptğ¦zf\mathbf{m}^{\rm zf} in (15) is given by

ğ¦zf=1Pâ€‹ğ‡ğ”»zfâˆ—â€‹(ğ‡ğ”»zfğ–³â€‹ğ‡ğ”»zfâˆ—)âˆ’1â€‹Ï•ğ”»zf,superscriptğ¦zf1ğ‘ƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‡superscriptğ”»zfsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‡superscriptğ”»zfğ–³superscriptsubscriptğ‡superscriptğ”»zf1subscriptbold-italic-Ï•superscriptğ”»zf\displaystyle\mathbf{m}^{\rm zf}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{P}}\mathbf{H}_{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}}^{*}\left(\mathbf{H}_{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{H}_{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}}^{*}\right)^{-1}\boldsymbol{\phi}_{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}}, (27)

and the aggregation error is

Ïµâ€‹(ğ¦zf,ğzf)=Ïƒ2Pâ€‹Ï•ğ”»zfğ–³â€‹(ğ‡ğ”»zfğ–³â€‹ğ‡ğ”»zfâˆ—)âˆ’1â€‹Ï•ğ”»zf.italic-Ïµsuperscriptğ¦zfsuperscriptğzfsuperscriptğœ2ğ‘ƒsuperscriptsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•superscriptğ”»zfğ–³superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‡superscriptğ”»zfğ–³superscriptsubscriptğ‡superscriptğ”»zf1subscriptbold-italic-Ï•superscriptğ”»zf\displaystyle\epsilon\left(\mathbf{m}^{\rm zf},\mathbf{B}^{\rm zf}\right)=\frac{\sigma^{2}}{P}\boldsymbol{\phi}_{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}}^{\mathsf{T}}\left(\mathbf{H}_{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{H}_{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}}^{*}\right)^{-1}\boldsymbol{\phi}_{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}}. (28)
Proof.

The ZF scheme is a mismatched MMSE coordination scheme in which Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} is postulated to be zero. This implies that LemmaÂ 3 is also valid for the ZF scheme by replacing ğ”»ğ”»\mathbb{D} with ğ”»zfsuperscriptğ”»zf{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}}. Consequently, ğ¦zfsuperscriptğ¦zf\mathbf{m}^{\mathrm{zf}} is given in terms of ğ”»zfsuperscriptğ”»zf{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}} from (26) by replacing ğ”»ğ”»\mathbb{D} with ğ”»zfsuperscriptğ”»zf{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}} and setting Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} to zero. The aggregation error is then derived by substituting ğ¦zfsuperscriptğ¦zf\mathbf{m}^{\mathrm{zf}} into (14). âˆ

Lemma 5 implies the same fact about ZF coordination: similar to the MMSE scheme, the root problem in ZF coordination is to find those devices that transmit with the maximum power. It is worth mentioning that ğ”»ğ”»\mathbb{D} and ğ”»zfsuperscriptğ”»zf{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}} are in general not identical; nevertheless, the problem of finding these discrete subsets also reduces to an integer programming problem. For the sake of brevity, we refer to this root problem as the subset selection problem in the remaining of this paper.

V Subset Selection for ZF Coordination

The computational complexity of the subset selection problem grows exponentially with the number of devices: there are in total 2Lâˆ’1superscript2ğ¿12^{L}-1 possible choices555Note that the empty set does not occur according to LemmasÂ 1 and 4. for the device subset. Thus, the complete search algorithm poses exponential complexity to the system. We hence look for a low-complexity approach to find a good choice for the device subset.

We start the derivations by defining the concept of a feasible setting for ZF coordination:

Definition 1.

The receiver ğ¦ğ¦\mathbf{m} and coefficients {bâ„“}subscriptğ‘â„“\left\{b_{\ell}\right\} describe a feasible ZF setting, if |bâ„“|2â‰¤Psuperscriptsubscriptğ‘â„“2ğ‘ƒ\left|b_{\ell}\right|^{2}\leq P and ğ¦ğ–³â€‹ğ¡â„“â€‹bâ„“=Ï•â„“superscriptğ¦ğ–³subscriptğ¡â„“subscriptğ‘â„“subscriptitalic-Ï•â„“\mathbf{m}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{h}_{\ell}b_{\ell}=\phi_{\ell} for â„“âˆˆ[L]â„“delimited-[]ğ¿\ell\in\left[L\right].

A feasible ZF setting only applies ZF on the received signal, i.e., it sets the first term in the right hand side of (9) zero, and ignores the optimization in (15) that minimizes the aggregation error. In this respect, we can see the ZF coordination scheme as a feasible ZF setting with minimal aggregation error. It is further easy to show that a feasible ZF setting is uniquely specified by its set of devices transmitting with power Pğ‘ƒP:

and bâ„“subscriptğ‘â„“b_{\ell} is determined from (13) for â„“âˆˆ[L]â„“delimited-[]ğ¿\ell\in\left[L\right].

The proof takes exactly the same steps as in LemmaÂ 5. We hence skip the proof. âˆ

This observation implies that not all the 2Lâˆ’1superscript2ğ¿12^{L}-1 settings determined by applying ZF over the choices of ğ•Šğ•Š\mathbb{S} describe a feasible ZF setting, and hence Czfsuperscriptğ¶zfC^{\mathrm{zf}} can be in general considerably smaller than 2Lâˆ’1superscript2ğ¿12^{L}-1.

Considering the above behavior, an algorithmic approach for approximating the ZF scheme is to track down the feasible ZF settings (or at least a subset of them). If there are only a few of them, i.e., Czfsuperscriptğ¶zfC^{\mathrm{zf}} is small; then, the ZF coordination scheme is readily found by a finite-dimensional search. Considering (14), we conclude that the aggregation error is

Ïµâ€‹(ğ¦zf,{bâ„“zf})=Ïƒ2â€‹(|c|2â€‹â€–ğ¡sâ€–2+|câŸ‚|2â€‹â€–ğ¡sâŸ‚â€–2)italic-Ïµsuperscriptğ¦zfsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘â„“zfsuperscriptğœ2superscriptğ‘2superscriptnormsubscriptğ¡ğ‘ 2superscriptsubscriptğ‘perpendicular-to2superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ¡ğ‘ perpendicular-to2\displaystyle\epsilon\left(\mathbf{m}^{\mathrm{zf}},\left\{b_{\ell}^{\mathrm{zf}}\right\}\right)=\sigma^{2}\left(\left|c\right|^{2}\;\left\|\mathbf{h}_{s}\right\|^{2}+\left|c_{\perp}\right|^{2}\left\|\mathbf{h}_{s}^{\perp}\right\|^{2}\right) (38)

that is minimized by setting |c|ğ‘\left|c\right| to its lower bound in (37) and câŸ‚=0subscriptğ‘perpendicular-to0c_{\perp}=0. This describes the feasible ZF setting with minimal aggregation error. Hence, the proof is concluded. âˆ

TheoremÂ 1 describes a sufficient condition under which the ZF scheme is determined closed-form. This condition is very likely to hold in practical scenarios in which few devices have significantly larger path-losses as compared with the others edge devices in the network. We consider an example of such a scenario throughout the numerical investigations. It is worth mentioning that in a homogeneous setting, i.e., Ï•â„“=Ï•subscriptitalic-Ï•â„“italic-Ï•\phi_{\ell}=\phi for â„“âˆˆ[L]â„“delimited-[]ğ¿\ell\in\left[L\right], with a single-antenna PS, the sufficient condition in Theorem 1 always hold. This is obvious, since in this case only the device with weakest channel should transmit with the maximum power for ZF coordination666Note that for MMSE coordination, this is in general not true, as also shown for a mathematically-similar problem in [25]..

V-A ZF Coordination without Closed-Form Solution

If the sufficient condition in TheoremÂ 1 does not hold, ZF coordination is found by searching over all feasible settings. This search procedure is exponentially hard. We hence develop a tractable algorithm which approximates the solution by polynomial complexity. In this respect, the following lemma, can be further useful to limit our search

Lemma 7.

If the condition in TheoremÂ 1 does not hold; then, there are at least two devices which transmit with the maximum power Pğ‘ƒP in ZF coordination.

Proof.

The proof is readily given by contradiction. We hence skip it here. âˆ

Considering LemmaÂ 7 and the earlier results on ZF coordination, we can have the following statements about the optimal ZF scheme, when it is not given by TheoremÂ 1:

  • â€¢

    It is a feasible ZF setting.

  • â€¢

    There are at least two devices with transmit power Pğ‘ƒP.

We further note that when all the devices transmit with power Pğ‘ƒP, a feasible ZF setting is always guaranteed to be determined: let bâ„“=Psubscriptğ‘â„“ğ‘ƒb_{\ell}=\sqrt{P} for â„“âˆˆ[L]â„“delimited-[]ğ¿\ell\in\left[L\right] and ğ¦ğ¦\mathbf{m} to be the one given in LemmaÂ 5 for ğ”»zf=[L]superscriptğ”»zfdelimited-[]ğ¿{\mathbb{D}^{{\mathrm{zf}}}}=\left[L\right]. These findings leads to this heuristic conclusion that a good approximate for the optimal ZF scheme is given by finding a feasible ZF setting with minimal number of devices transmitting with power Pğ‘ƒP. This heuristic conclusion leads us to a tree-based algorithm which is presented in the sequel.

Remark 1.

As mentioned in SectionÂ II, throughout the paper we assume Nâ‰¥Lğ‘ğ¿N\geq L. This however does not restrict the scope of analyses. In fact, the derivations are further valid for settings with N<Lğ‘ğ¿N<L when we limit the subset selection problem to be solved for subsets with |ğ•Š|â‰¤Nğ•Šğ‘\left|\mathbb{S}\right|\leq N.

V-B A Tree-Based Search Scheme

We now present a tree-based algorithm to find the optimal ZF scheme. Although its core idea comes from our heuristic conclusions, it is shown that with full complexity this algorithm is exact. Before we present the algorithm, we state the following lemma which serves as the analytical foundation of the tree-based algorithm:

Lemma 8.

Let (ğ¦1,{b1â€‹â„“})subscriptğ¦1subscriptğ‘1â„“\left(\mathbf{m}_{1},\left\{b_{1\ell}\right\}\right) and (ğ¦2,{b2â€‹â„“})subscriptğ¦2subscriptğ‘2â„“\left(\mathbf{m}_{2},\left\{b_{2\ell}\right\}\right) describeÂ twoÂ feasible ZF setting for coordination. Denote the set of devices transmitting with power Pğ‘ƒP in these two settings with ğ•Š1subscriptğ•Š1\mathbb{S}_{1} and ğ•Š2subscriptğ•Š2\mathbb{S}_{2}, respectively. If ğ•Š1âŠ†ğ•Š2subscriptğ•Š1subscriptğ•Š2\mathbb{S}_{1}\subseteq\mathbb{S}_{2}; then,

Ïµâ€‹(ğ¦1,{b1â€‹â„“})â‰¤Ïµâ€‹(ğ¦2,{b2â€‹â„“}).italic-Ïµsubscriptğ¦1subscriptğ‘1â„“italic-Ïµsubscriptğ¦2subscriptğ‘2â„“\displaystyle\epsilon\left(\mathbf{m}_{1},\left\{b_{1\ell}\right\}\right)\leq\epsilon\left(\mathbf{m}_{2},\left\{b_{2\ell}\right\}\right). (39)
Proof.

The proof is readily concluded by the fact that the feasible region of the error minimization problem for subset ğ•Š1subscriptğ•Š1\mathbb{S}_{1} contains the feasible region of the optimization problem defined with subset ğ•Š2subscriptğ•Š2\mathbb{S}_{2}. This implies that the error obtained by the former minimization is smaller than the one in the latter. This concludes the proof. âˆ

The above result implies that while searching for the optimal ZF coordination, those feasible ZF settings whose corresponding subsets include other feasible subsets can be further ignored777From LemmaÂ 7, weÂ furtherÂ conclude that this search is restricted to |S|â‰¥2ğ‘†2\left|S\right|\geq 2.. We hence can graphically visualize the search for the optimal feasible setting via a tree: consider a graph whose nodes denote those subsets of [L]delimited-[]ğ¿\left[L\right] that describe feasible ZF settings. The node corresponding to ğ•ŠâŠ†[L]ğ•Šdelimited-[]ğ¿\mathbb{S}\subseteq\left[L\right] is connected to its children which are the subsets of ğ•Šğ•Š\mathbb{S} describing feasible ZF settings. Any set ğ•Šâ‰ [L]ğ•Šdelimited-[]ğ¿\mathbb{S}\neq\left[L\right] is further connected to its parent which is the feasible ZF set ğ•Š~~ğ•Š\tilde{\mathbb{S}} containing ğ•Šğ•Š\mathbb{S}, i.e., ğ•ŠâŠ‚ğ•Š~ğ•Š~ğ•Š\mathbb{S}\subset\tilde{\mathbb{S}}. If there are multiple choices for the parent of ğ•Šğ•Š\mathbb{S}; then, the set with largest cardinality is selected888If there are multiple nodes with largest cardinality, the we choose the parent among them at random.. This way we built a tree whose root is [L]delimited-[]ğ¿\left[L\right] and whose cardinality of the sets corresponding to the nodes decreases as we move towards the leaves.

Example 1.

Consider a network with L=4ğ¿4L=4 edge devices and N=5ğ‘5N=5 antennas at the PS. Let Ï•â„“=0.25subscriptitalic-Ï•â„“0.25\phi_{\ell}=0.25 for all devices and P=1ğ‘ƒ1P=1. The channel matrix is further as follows

ğ‡=[0.300.460.390.19âˆ’0.550.32âˆ’0.520.040.32âˆ’0.14âˆ’0.48âˆ’0.110.720.13âˆ’0.370.180.21âˆ’0.36âˆ’1.32âˆ’0.23].ğ‡matrix0.300.460.390.190.550.320.520.040.320.140.480.110.720.130.370.180.210.361.320.23\displaystyle\mathbf{H}=\begin{bmatrix}0.30&0.46&0.39&0.19\\ -0.55&0.32&-0.52&0.04\\ 0.32&-0.14&-0.48&-0.11\\ 0.72&0.13&-0.37&0.18\\ 0.21&-0.36&-1.32&-0.23\\ \end{bmatrix}. (40)

The ZF tree for this network is shown in Fig. 1. As observed, the root is {1,2,3,4}1234\left\{1,2,3,4\right\}.

Lemma 8 implies that the optimal ZF scheme with minimal aggregation error is among the leaves of the tree representing ZF feasible settings. Therefore, the problem of finding the optimal ZF scheme reduces to a search for the leaf with minimal error, i.e., the leaf with minimal norm of the receiver. It is worth mentioning that this search is still exponentially complex, since in general construction of the tree requires 2Lâˆ’1superscript2ğ¿12^{L}-1 feasibility checks. Its visual representation however describes a tractable approximation approach: starting from the root, we move towards the leaves in a step-wise fashion. In each step, we go from a parent to the child whose aggregation error is minimum among all the children. The search is finally over as we arrive at a leaf. This leaf is taken as the approximate of the solution.

V-C Approximate ZF Coordination

The proposed tree-based search lead to an approximation of ZF coordination which we refer to as approximate ZF (AZF). The details on this algorithm are as follows:

  1. 1.

    We initiate the search at the root of the tree by setting ğ•Š(0)=[L]superscriptğ•Š0delimited-[]ğ¿\mathbb{S}^{(0)}=\left[L\right]. The initial receiver ğ¦(0)superscriptğ¦0\mathbf{m}^{(0)} and scaling coefficients are further found via LemmaÂ 6.

  2. 2.

    At step iğ‘–i, we consider all subsets of ğ•Š(i)superscriptğ•Šğ‘–\mathbb{S}^{(i)} that differ with ğ•Š(i)superscriptğ•Šğ‘–\mathbb{S}^{(i)} in only one element. For each subset, we determine the receiver from ğ¦(i)superscriptğ¦ğ‘–\mathbf{m}^{(i)} and the corresponding channel vectors via rank-one update of matrix inverse; see [26]. We then calculate the scaling coefficients and check if they satisfy the transmit power constraint. If the power constraint is satisfied, we collect the subset as a feasible ZF subset of ğ•Š(i)superscriptğ•Šğ‘–\mathbb{S}^{(i)}.

  3. 3.

    Among the feasible ZF subsets of ğ•Š(i)superscriptğ•Šğ‘–\mathbb{S}^{(i)}, we set ğ•Š(i+1)superscriptğ•Šğ‘–1\mathbb{S}^{(i+1)} to be the one whose receiver has minimal norm.

The algorithm stops at step iTsubscriptğ‘–Ti_{\rm T}, where there is no feasible ZF subsets for the set ğ•Š(iT)superscriptğ•Šsubscriptğ‘–T\mathbb{S}^{(i_{\rm T})}.

The AZF scheme needs to search among Lâ€‹(L+1)/2ğ¿ğ¿12L\left(L+1\right)/2 subsets in the worst-case scenario, and hence is computationally tractable. It can be further extended by considering multiple dominant paths of the tree. Such an extension can potentially lead to a more accurate approximation of the ZF schemeÂ atÂ the expense of higher computational complexity.

VI Subset Selection for MMSE Coordination

We now get back to the MMSE scheme and utilize the framework developed for ZF coordination to design a tractable algorithm for approximating the MMSE scheme. We start the derivations by defining the less-intuitive concept of a feasible MMSE setting. Before stating the definition, let us look back to the key properties of the MMSE scheme: from LemmasÂ 1 and 2, we know that the scaling coefficients in this scheme are either Pğ‘ƒ\sqrt{P} or satisfy the ZF constraint. We further note that given the set of devices transmitting with power Pğ‘ƒP, the receiver can be found via (26). These features are dual to those satisfied by the ZF scheme. We hence invoke DefinitionÂ 1 and define a feasible setting for MMSE coordination as follows:

Definition 2.

Consider the subset of devices ğ•ŠâŠ†[L]ğ•Šdelimited-[]ğ¿\mathbb{S}\subseteq\left[L\right] whose cardinality is |ğ•Š|=Sğ•Šğ‘†\left|\mathbb{S}\right|=S. Let ğ¦ğ¦\mathbf{m} be

(41)

Let |bâ„“|=Psubscriptğ‘â„“ğ‘ƒ\left|b_{\ell}\right|=\sqrt{P} for â„“âˆˆğ•Šâ„“ğ•Š\ell\in\mathbb{S} and determine bâ„“subscriptğ‘â„“b_{\ell} for â„“âˆ‰ğ•Šâ„“ğ•Š\ell\notin\mathbb{S} from the equation ğ¦ğ–³â€‹ğ¡â„“â€‹bâ„“=Ï•â„“superscriptğ¦ğ–³subscriptğ¡â„“subscriptğ‘â„“subscriptitalic-Ï•â„“\mathbf{m}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{h}_{\ell}b_{\ell}=\phi_{\ell}. The set ğ•Šğ•Š\mathbb{S} is said to describe a feasible MMSE setting for coordination, if |bâ„“|2<Psuperscriptsubscriptğ‘â„“2ğ‘ƒ\left|b_{\ell}\right|^{2}<P for â„“âˆ‰ğ•Šâ„“ğ•Š\ell\notin\mathbb{S}.

LemmasÂ 1 and 2 along with (26) imply that the subset of devices transmitting with power Pğ‘ƒP in the MMSE scheme,Â i.e., ğ”»ğ”»\mathbb{D}, describes a feasible MMSE setting. In other words, similar to ZF coordination, this definition relaxes the MMSE scheme by dropping the optimality constraint. We next follow the same steps as for ZF coordination to show that the MMSE scheme is given by searching over the tree of feasible settings for the smallest subset.

VI-A Properties of Feasible MMSE Settings

Similar to Theorem 1, a sufficient condition can be derived for MMSE coordination, under which the set ğ”»ğ”»\mathbb{D}, and thus the MMSE scheme, is determined in closed-form.

Theorem 2.

Let sğ‘ s be index of the device whose channel norm is smallest, i.e.,

Denote the entry â„“â„“\ell of ğ ğ \mathbf{g} with gâ„“subscriptgâ„“{\mathrm{g}}_{\ell} and assume that |gs|â‰¤|gâ„“|subscriptgğ‘ subscriptgâ„“\left|{\mathrm{g}}_{s}\right|\leq\left|{\mathrm{g}}_{\ell}\right| for all â„“âˆˆ[L]â„“delimited-[]ğ¿\ell\in\left[L\right] with equality holding for devices in set ğ•ŠâŠ†[L]ğ•Šdelimited-[]ğ¿\mathbb{S}\subseteq\left[L\right]. Proof.

The proof follows similar steps as those taken for the proof of TheoremÂ 1. We hence skip the details. âˆ

TheoremÂ 1 describes the sufficient condition for tractable calculation of the MMSE scheme. For networks which do not satisfy this condition, one can show that similar findings, as those given in SectionsÂ V-A and V-B for ZF coordination, are reported as well in this case. In particular, we can show that feasible MMSE settings reduce in aggregation error as their corresponding subset of devices with maximum transmit power shrinks.

Lemma 9.

Let (ğ¦1,{b1â€‹â„“})subscriptğ¦1subscriptğ‘1â„“\left(\mathbf{m}_{1},\left\{b_{1\ell}\right\}\right) and (ğ¦2,{b2â€‹â„“})subscriptğ¦2subscriptğ‘2â„“\left(\mathbf{m}_{2},\left\{b_{2\ell}\right\}\right) describeÂ twoÂ feasible MMSE settings for coordination whose corresponding subsets are ğ•Š1subscriptğ•Š1\mathbb{S}_{1} and ğ•Š2subscriptğ•Š2\mathbb{S}_{2}, respectively. If ğ•Š1âŠ†ğ•Š2subscriptğ•Š1subscriptğ•Š2\mathbb{S}_{1}\subseteq\mathbb{S}_{2}; then,

Proof.

The proof is similar to the proof of Lemma 8. âˆ

VI-B Approximate MMSE Coordination

LemmaÂ 9 indicates that the MMSE scheme can be found by searching for the MMSE feasible setting with smallest subset. We hence follow the same approach as in SectionÂ V-B and build the tree of feasible MMSE schemes. Due to its similarity, we skip the definition of the tree and refer the reader to SectionÂ V-B. We now approximately find the MMSE scheme by moving step-wise from the root towards the leaves while in each step we choose the child whose aggregation error is minimum among all the children connected to the parent.

The proposed tree-based search algorithm for MMSE coordination can be summarized as follows:

  1. 1.

    We initiate the search at the root of the tree by setting ğ•Š(0)=[L]superscriptğ•Š0delimited-[]ğ¿\mathbb{S}^{(0)}=\left[L\right]. The initial receiver ğ¦(0)superscriptğ¦0\mathbf{m}^{(0)} and scaling coefficients are further found from DefinitionÂ 2.

  2. 2.

    At step iğ‘–i, we consider all subsets of ğ•Š(i)superscriptğ•Šğ‘–\mathbb{S}^{(i)} thatÂ differÂ with ğ•Š(i)superscriptğ•Šğ‘–\mathbb{S}^{(i)} in only one element. For each subset, we determine the receiver from ğ¦(i)superscriptğ¦ğ‘–\mathbf{m}^{(i)} and the channel vectors via rank-one update. We then calculate the scaling coefficients and check if they describe a feasible MMSE setting.

  3. 3.

    Among the feasible MMSE subsets of ğ•Š(i)superscriptğ•Šğ‘–\mathbb{S}^{(i)}, we set ğ•Š(i+1)superscriptğ•Šğ‘–1\mathbb{S}^{(i+1)} to be the one whose aggregation error is minimum.

The algorithm stops, when no feasible MMSE subsets is found. We refer to this algorithm in the sequel as approximate MMSE (AMMSE) scheme.

VII Numerical results

In the section, we examine the efficiency of the proposed algorithms through numerical experiments. To this end, we consider a simple network whose uplink channels experience a standard i.i.d. Rayleigh fading process with fixed path-loss. The channel coefficients are hence written as hâ„“,n=tâ„“â€‹fâ„“,nsubscriptâ„â„“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¡â„“subscriptğ‘“â„“ğ‘›h_{\ell,n}=t_{\ell}f_{\ell,n}, where fâ„“,nâˆ¼ğ’â€‹ğ’©â€‹(0,1/N)similar-tosubscriptğ‘“â„“ğ‘›ğ’ğ’©01ğ‘f_{\ell,n}\sim\mathcal{CN}(0,1/N) models small-scale fading, and tâ„“subscriptğ‘¡â„“t_{\ell} captures the path-loss between the PS and device â„“â„“\ell. We further assume an FL setting in which Ï•â„“=1/Lsubscriptitalic-Ï•â„“1ğ¿\phi_{\ell}=1/L for â„“âˆˆ[L]â„“delimited-[]ğ¿\ell\in\left[L\right].

In this network, we coordinate the devices using the proposed scheme, i.e., AZF and AMMSE. For sake of comparison, we further evaluate the optimal ZF and MMSE schemes by performing a complete search over the leaves of their corresponding trees. To keep the simulations for the optimum case tractable, we limit the number of devices in the network.

VII-A Coordination Performance

Fig. 2 shows the aggregation error against the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) in the network, defined as SNR=P/Ïƒ2SNRğ‘ƒsuperscriptğœ2\mathrm{SNR}={P}/{\sigma^{2}}, for L=4ğ¿4L=4 and N=8ğ‘8N=8. For this figure, the path-losses are set to tâ„“=1subscriptğ‘¡â„“1t_{\ell}=1 for â„“âˆˆ[L]â„“delimited-[]ğ¿\ell\in\left[L\right]. As the figure shows, for a small number of devices, the approximate schemes, i.e., AZF and AMMSE, perform optimally.

We next investigate the impact of network asymmetry on both the coordination approaches in Fig.Â  3, where we plot the same figure for two different scenarios: the first scenario is as the one considered in Fig.Â 2, and the other considers the setting in which the path-loss of one of the devices is 101010 dB below the others. As shown in the figure, ZF coordination is more sensitive to the non-uniformity of the path-losses as compared to the MMSE scheme. This is in particular severe at low SNRs which is often the case in current wireless networks.

As the next experiment, we plot the aggregation error against the load of the system that is defined as Î¾=N/Lğœ‰ğ‘ğ¿\xi=N/L in Fig. 4. For numerical tractability of the optimal schemes, we set L=4ğ¿4L=4. The SNR is further set to logâ¡SNR=12SNR12\log\mathrm{SNR}=12 dB, and the path-loss is set to tâ„“=1subscriptğ‘¡â„“1t_{\ell}=1 for â„“âˆˆ[L]â„“delimited-[]ğ¿\ell\in\left[L\right]. As observed, the tree-base approximates closely track the optimal schemes. Furthermore, the gap between the optimal and approximated schemes shrinks as the load grows.

VII-B Complexity of the Proposed Schemes

As a metric of complexity, we define the check time to be the number of subsets being checked in the tree-based search of the algorithm. Fig. 5 and Fig. 6 show the average check time for AZF or AMMSE algorithms against the SNR and load, respectively. Here, L=4ğ¿4L=4 and N=8ğ‘8N=8, and the check time is averaged over multiple channel realizations. The devices are assumed to be uniformly distributed in the network, i.e., the path-loss is assumed to the same for all the devices. As the figures depict, the complexity of the AZF scheme only varies against the load, while the complexity of the AMMSE scheme scales with both the load and channel quality. The figures further demonstrate that the check time for AMMSE is always less than AZF. This is a favorable behavior, since AMMSE leads to less aggregation error, as well. Fig.Â 6 further implies that the average check time of both the algorithms reduces by growth of Nğ‘N and converges to L+1ğ¿1L+1. This follows the fact that at high system loads, the channel vectors become statistically orthogonal, and hence all the devices transmit with the maximum power. As the result, both the algorithms stop at the root, after checking the feasibility of their Lğ¿L children.

As the last experiment, we investigate the impacts of a non-uniform distribution of the device in the network on tree-based search complexity. Fig. 7 shows the average check time for the same setting as in Fig.Â 6, when one of the devices is located, such that its path-loss is 101010 dB below the path-losses of the other devices. As the figure shows, this asymmetry increases even further the gap between the complexity of AZF and AMMSE leading to this conclusion that AMMSE proposes a more robust behavior as compared with the AZF.

VIII Conclusions

Low-complexity algorithms have been proposed for MMSE and ZF coordination in OTA-FL. The algorithms find efficient approximation of the optimal MMSE and ZF schemes using a tree-based search algorithm which solves the equivalent subset selection problem. Our numerical investigations depict that the proposed algorithms track closely the optimal schemes.

The analytical results of this study indicate that both the MMSE and ZF coordination schemes deal with the same level of hardness, while the former leads to a lower aggregation error. The numerical investigations further reveal that the tree-based approximation of MMSE coordination results in less computational complexity and more robustness as compared to the approximated ZF scheme. Considering the favorable behavior of the MMSE scheme with respect to performance and complexity, one concludes that MMSE is a better approach for device coordination in OTA-FL.
